bioghist.p: Richard Thomas was born in West Whiteland Township, Chester County, on October 30, 1744, a descendant of Richard Ap Thomas of Whitford Garden, Flintshire, North Wales. A Quaker, Thomas was appointed a colonel of the 5th Battalion of Association in Chester County by John Morton on April 19, 1776. He was disowned from Uwchlan’s Friends Meeting for his military service on August 10, 1775 . His brother George remained in the Society of Friends, but according to a letter in the collection, seems to have aided the Revolutionary cause in other ways. After the war, George was a member of the Commission that planned the “Philadelphia-Lancaster Turnpike.” George died after contracting yellow fever in 1793. During the Revolutionary War, Col. Thomas participated in a campaign into New Jersey (as far as Amboy) as part of the military’s efforts to protect Philadelphia. Thomas was appointed Brigadier General of Chester County on April 19, 1793, (see Box 2, Folder 4), but declined the promotion. He began his political career in 1786, serving as an assemblyman until his election as a State Senator in 1790. In 1794 he became a member of Congress for the fourth, fifth and sixth sessions (1794, 1796, 1798). Thomas was married to Thomazine Downing on October 20, 1774, at Uwchlan Meeting. They had eight children: Richard, Mary, George, Jacob, Phebe, Thomazine, Samuel and William. Richard married Rebecca Malin. Thomazine married William Ashbridge and Phebe married Samuel Hains. Col. Richard Thomas died January 19, 1832 in his eighty-eighth year.

scopecontent.p: Documents in the collection give not only a detailed account of Chester County and U.S. history, but also the personal side of the Thomas family. Military records include “Accounts of a Revolutionary War Soldier, Richard Thomas 1776-1777,” and “A Size Book of Firelocks 1776/Field Book 1775, Richard Thomas.” These record the activity of the Chester County Militia during Thomas’ service in the Revolutionary War and are a record of supplies. Thomas also wrote numerous letters to friends and loved ones back in Pennsylvania during 1800-1801 when he was with the first session of Congress to serve in Washington City. Collection also includes his mill account book along with related receipts and letters. Includes many family letters and poetry. Topics include his trip across New York State in 1819. A report of this trip was later published in the Village Record newspaper. Also includes a 1796 travel journal of a trip to Madeira by Samuel Hains.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
